Book: Die Kunst des reinen Satzes in der Musik
Author: Kirnberger, Johann Philipp

Book: Handbuch zur Harmonielehre und für den Generalbaß
Author: Vogler, Georg Joseph

Book: Versuch einer geordneten Theorie der Tonsetzkunst
Author: Weber, Gottfried
notes_1: s.201: Multilayered RN analysis; s.219: 3-layered one

Book: System der Musik-Wissenschaft und der Praktischen Composition
Author: Logier, Johann Bernhard

Book: A Catechism of the Rudiments of Harmony and Thorough Bass
Author: Hamilton, James Alexander

Book: Traité Complet de la Théorie Et de la Pratique de l'Harmonie
Author: Fétis, François-Joseph
notes_1: pp.133: figured bass syntax

Author: Lobe, Johann Christian
notes_1: *: Uses arabic numerals pretty much as we currently use Roman numerals, to indicate scale degrees, usually root scale degrees of a chord

Book: Vollständige Harmonie-und Generalbasslehre und Einleitung zur Composition
Author: Meister, Johann Georg
notes_1: *: Dual chord labels + Roman numeral annotations

Author: Sechter, Simon
notes_1: *: Mostly uses a chord-label-like notation, which has some entries of the form "D F" for a single chord that do not make a lot of sense

Book: A rudimentary and practical treatise on music
Author: Spencer, Charles Child

Book: Course of Harmony: Being a Manual of Instruction in the Principles of Thorough-bass and Harmony
Author: Southard, Lucien H.
notes_1: *: Almost entirely relies on figured bass

Book: Harmonielehre: Zunächst zum Gebrauch für Schullehrer-Seminarien
Author: Volckmar, Wilhelm Valentin
notes_1: *: Roman numerals used to indicate theme I and II in motivic analysis; not relevant for harmony or chords

Author: Richter, Ernst Friedrich
notes_1: pp.115: very cryptic but interesting notation for modulations; *: Chord labels too

Author: von Oettingen, Arthur
notes_1: *: Not many music notation examples, mostly text

Author: Ouseley, Frederick Arthur Gore
notes_1: *: Almost exclusively based on figured bass

Author: Tiersch, Otto
notes_1: *: Completely different system to anything else

Author: Tiersch, Otto
notes_1: *: Seems like he abandoned his older system entirely for figured bass and Roman numerals

Author: Tracy, James
notes_1: pp.77: has a weird syntax for sevenths (e.g., no 7 written on dominant seventh); *: Has chord labels as well, puts the diminished circle at the beginning instead of the end, weird syntax for modulations too (no colon), found the table of relationships of keys

Author: Bussler, Ludwig
notes_1: *: This is one of the first examples of concurrent Roman numerals and figured bass, possibly explaining the later practice of denoting inversions using stacks of arabic numerals next to the Roman numerals
notes_2: There appear to be two books here, both by Bussler

Author: Emery, Stephen
notes_1: *: Description of augmented sixth chords as "Augmented Sixth Chord (Italian)", "Augmented Six-Four-Three" (French), and Augmented Six-Five (German). For those chords, the author starts to mix Roman numerals and inversions

Author: Kistler, Cyrill
notes_1: *: Used Roman numerals for enumerating seventh chords, but went beyond vii, so it was basically an enum, not a scale degree
Roman numerals?: No* (used in explanations, but not in musical examples)

Book: Harmony: Historic Points and Modern Methods of Instruction
Author: Bowman, Edward Morris

Book: Traité Complet d'Harmonie Théorique Et Pratique
Author: Durand, Emile
notes_1: *: Roman numerals here refer to degrees, but not chord roots

Author: Riemann, Hugo
notes_1: *: A different notation system
Roman numerals?: Scarce (for different purposes than chords, it seems)

Author: Jadassohn, Salomon
notes_1: *: Another case of fast changes of key using colons, not the slash "/" syntax. Augmented triads denoted with a single quote III'

Author: Riemann, Hugo
notes_1: *: Very weird syntax with Roman numerals to denote modulation. Also use of the strikethrough V as some sort of secondary dominant

Book: A System of Harmony for Teacher and Pupil
Author: Broekhoven, John Andrew
notes_1: pp.106: chord labels in the modulation section; *: Augmented chords indicated with a superscript comma (V'). Multirow key analysis

Author: Shepard, Frank Hartson
notes_1: pp.10: The first occurence of fractional notations; *: Also used the single-quote (') notation for augmented triads

Book: Die Kunst zu Modulieren und zu Präludieren
Author: Jadassohn, Salomon
Riemann, Hugo
notes_1: *: Proposed a different notation for augmented (+)

Book: Traité complet d'harmonie, théorique, pratique, vocale & instrumentale
Author: Vivier, Albert-Joseph

Book: The theory and practice of tone-relations
Author: Goetschius, Percy
notes_1: *: The book says "21st" edition, not sure if I am reading something from 1892 or much later. It mixes figured bass (inversions) and Roman numerals

Author: Goodrich, Alfred John
notes_1: ch.48: Figured bass; *: Roman numerals are actually used, but they refer to seventh chords with dissonances in a very weird nomenclature

Book: Schule Der Accord-Verbindungen: Eine Harmonielehre Fur Schulen Und Zum Selbstunterrichts
Author: Buwa, Johann
notes_1: *: Uses the single quote (') notation for augmented

Book: Practical harmony: A comprehensive system of musical theory on a French basis
Author: Norris, Homer Albert
Shepard, Frank Hartson
notes_1: pp.106: First occurrence I have found of secondary dominant notation in an English-language book; pp.117: using numeric inversions for I64, even in plain-text descriptions; pp.137: Augmented sixth chords are, at first, not referred by names (FR,GER,IT) but by figures. Then, he says "these names are given with reference to the nations which (supposedly) first used them; pp.179: The description in is exactly how a tonicization is written nowadays; pp.18: features numeric inversions; *: Using the single-quote notation for augmented triads;

Author: Chadwick, George Whitefield
notes_1: pp.28: inversions go beyond 6 and 64, also includes 43; pp:64: Inversions made it to Roman numeral sequences without music notation; *: There are modulation examples where colons are used to change the key at every chord. Mentions N6 chords. Very explicit explanation for numeric inversions. Uses Riemann notation for augmented triads

Author: Cutter, Benjamin
notes_1: *: Using numeric chord inversions; also using Riemann's notation for augmented triads. Different notation bII for Neapolitans and IV6+ for augsix

Author: Bridge, Frederick
notes_1: pp.16: Example of Roman numerals, otherwise scarce

Author: Halm, August
notes_1: *: Uses a special syntax to denote secondary dominants. I-V I, indicating that the I is also a V in a different key, then I is the resolution on that key. The key change is indicated above the staff; later, he uses an annotation of V-V for a secondary dominant; all the other examples are I-V or I-IV, but the V-V is a nondiatonic chord, it is very similar to V/V; the XVII example is another very clear V-V
notes_2: almost everything is plain-text with no musical examples; it does use Roman numerals with clear note spellings on pp.46, using that as a reference to say that there is indeed RN notation

Book: Harmonic Analysis: A Course in the Analysis of the Chords and of the Non-harmonic Tones to Be Found in Music, Classic and Modern
Author: Cutter, Benjamin
notes_1: pp.4: Description of inversions with arabic numerals AND letters

Author: Riemann, Hugo
notes_1: *: There are roman numerals, they represent descending intervals

Book: Modern harmony in its theory and practice
Author: Foote, Arthur and Spalding, Walter R.
notes_1: *: Nice explanation about the syntax. Interesting multi-row Roman numerals with not key indication. Uses the + notation for augmented triads

Book: Neue Musikalische Theorien und Phantasien: Harmonielehre
Author: Schenker, Heinrich
notes_1: Using a syntax of VI=II(Cdur), similar to a tonicization syntax, here uses the word "Trugschluss" ("fallacy") in that annotation; probably, in this context trugschluss means "deceptive cadence", because he also talks about halbschluss (half cadence?); Somewhat close to the denominator notation in pp. 79; modal mixture notation in pp.120; Neapolitan is expressed as bII (phrygisch), instead of N[6]; pp.190: modal mixture of a minor, the minor tonic is indicated with a natural I, but is not consistent (missing on the last I before going to G major), in the G-major modulation, a minor is taken as II of G-major in a multirow annotation, then turns into bII (Neapolitan of G), then the music goes towards D-Major, there is probably a mistake in the book where it says "nach G-dur" i'd expect it to be "nach D-dur"; pp.298: there is a fraction notation, it behaves like a multirow Roman numeral analysis, with the target key on the denominator

Book: Lessons of Harmony: Complete. Parts I and II
Author: Heacox, Arthur E.
notes_1: pp.14: the coexistence of figured bass and Roman numerals; pp.144: the syntax of the Neapolitan chord in root position and second inversion

Author: Capellen, Georg
notes_1: pp.83: sporadic use of Roman numeral, caseless; *: uses single-quote notation for augmented triad

Author: Loewengard, Max Julius
notes_1: pp.45: I64 is written with numeric inversion but ii6 is not; pp.48: some secondary dominant notation

Book: A manual of harmony for schools
Author: Gladstone, Francis Edward

Book: The nature of music; original harmony in one voice by Julius Klauser
Author: Klauser, Julius
notes_1: pp.94: Roman numerals introduced for scale-degrees; *: later in the book, more complex RNs introduced, the syntax is case-sensitive standard except for augmented triads, which are strikethrough capitals

Book: Principes du Système Musical Et de l'Harmonie Théorique Et Appliquée
Author: Vinée, Anselme
notes_1: *: No figured bass annotations either
Roman numerals?: No (some in broad explanations of diatonic degrees)

Book: A practical introduction to composition: Harmony simplified
Author: York, Francis L.
notes_1: pp.19: Inversions by letter explained in major triads; pp.91 shows the notation for Fr, It, Ger, all of these (and the neapolitan) are indicated as scale degrees, II #iv, #iv, and bII respectively

Author: White, William Alfred
notes_1: p.18: Shows an example of a modulation from C to G, the pivot chord is written in multirow form, without key indication. The secondary row is immediately withdrown, the new Roman numerals are presented in the main row and now correspond to the target key (G major); pp.110: Features an example of modulations and secondary dominants, the secondary dominants are in parenthesis, the key changes do not propagate *: the notation is very lossy, it requires the human analyst to fill many gaps. Talks about "side-stepping" and "borrowing". Secondary dominants written as C:I (F V) IV
notes_2: use as an example of consistent notation

Author: Gardner, Carl E.
notes_1: pp.42: use of single-quote notation for augmented triads

Author: Mokrejs, John
notes_1: pp.79: Introducing the VofV notation, several degrees on denominator but only V on numerator; pp.87: neapolitan is indicated as "Neap. 6th"; pp.115: his notation for multirow RNs doesn't seem consistent, sometimes indicates the key between the grandstaff, sometimes not, sometimes changes row, sometimes not *: case-unsensitive notation of Roman numerals
notes_2: use as an example of inconsistent notation

Author: Kallenberg, Siegfried Garibaldi
notes_1: *: Modulations have several layers of Roman numerals with key and scale degrees indicated

Book: Die Diatonisch-Rhythmische Harmonisation der Gregorianischen Choralmelodien
Author: Molitor, Gregor
Riemann, Hugo
Roman numerals?: Yes (do not mean what you expect)

Author: Lenormand, René
notes_1: *: Translation to English available here: https://imslp.org/wiki/%C3%89tude_sur_l%27harmonie_moderne_(Lenormand%2C_Ren%C3%A9)

Book: Etude sur les Intervalles Diatoniques Et Chromatiques
Author: Gilson, Paul
notes_1: *: The notation here seems clearly Riemannian; probably explains why the other notation also feels Riemannian with more complex symbols

Author: Spencer, Stanhope Reid
notes_1: pp.56: multirow analysis; pp.72: Uses the III+ notation for augmented triads; *: Inversions are written between staffs. This is similar in several other books. It does seem like the numeric inversions used nowaday evolved from figured bass indications that were originally independent of the Roman numeral; Use of multi-row multi-key annotations in modulation, very similar to how it is done today

Book: Modern Harmony: its Explanation and Application
Author: Hull, Arthur Eaglefield
notes_1: pp.79: Use of Roman numerals

Author: Orem, Preston Ware
notes_1: pp.95: using the single-quote notation for III'

Author: Heacox, Arthur E.
notes_1: Vol2-pp.3: N6 notation for neapolitan; Vol2-pp.24: A common-tone diminished seventh written as ~IVdim7

Author: Robinson, Franklin
notes_1: pp.93: First example of chord inversion notation; *: Inversions are written with numbers (0--2); I have never seen this notation anywhere other than this book

Author: Anger, Joseph Humfrey and Clough-Leighter, Henry
notes_1: pp.123: Also using the inversion syntax seen in Robinson (1918); *: Weird syntax with "+" for major and "-" for minor

Author: Watt, Henry J.
notes_1: *: More an early book of music perception than music theory

Author: Deveaux, Orpha-F.
notes_1: pp.61: An example with Roman numerals; *: The modulation examples have an underbracket with roman numerals referring to keys (modulationstart - modulationend); Everything else is figured bass; Ocassionally, roman numerals also used to refer to chords in explanations
Roman numerals?: Yes (used to refer to keys in the modulation section)

Author: Gilson, Paul
notes_1: pp.21: Fractional notation; pp.49: A clear example of the fractional notation; pp.90: An example of VV notation (dominant of the dominant); *: A clearly Riemannian system with Ir to denote vi; where the "r" means "relative"; also makes use of the convention V64 for the Cad64; There is another VV convention for secondary dominants; Numerator/Denominator notation used, arguably, it means "or" instead of "of"

Book: The Rudiments of Music and Elementary Harmony
Author: Ham, Albert

Book: Melody and Harmony: A Treatise for the Teacher and the Student
Author: Macpherson, Charles Stewart
notes_1: pp.199: Nb used for Neapolitan; pp.245: the syntax for augsix chords (striked VI and striked II); *: Very peculiar notation, Roman numerals used in melodization exercises, only for dominant chords, and  key regions (tonicizations) are indicated with a bracket below the staff and the name of the key; In further exercises, other degrees are introduced; inversions indicated with letters

Book: Der Aufbau der Kadenz und Anderes
Author: Koch, Friedrich E.
Alchin, Carolyn A.
notes_1: pp.124: Using the single-quote notation for Augmented triads; pp.161: Notation of the Neapolitan (N6); *: Inversions are Arabic numerals {3, 5, 7} where the number indicates the scale degree acting as the bass
notes_2: An example of an inversion notation that is neither the numeric or by-letter categories I mention

Book: Aufgaben für den Unterricht in der Harmonielehre
Author: Knorr, Iwan
notes_1: pp.19: Has some interesting syntax of Cad64 with I64 written with a (V) underneath. Applies the same idea to other suspensions like I4 (V)

Author: Dubois, Théodore
notes_1: *: Couldn't find a single Roman numeral

Author: Klatte, Wilhelm
notes_1: pp.61: Using an arrow to notate applied chords; *: Riemannian notation

Book: Neue Musikalische Theorien und Phantasien: Kontrapunkt, Zweiter Teil
Author: Schenker, Heinrich
Schoenberg, Arnold
notes_1: pp.62: case-unsensitive notation; pp.135: Example of problematic case-unsensitive notation, can't distinguish between v and V without having the score

Author: Koechlin, Charles
notes_1: pp.26: The Roman numerals still refer to a scale degree instead of a chord

Author: Wedge, George A.
notes_1: pp.129: An example of the inversion notation
notes_2: He seems to use the numeric system of {1, 2, 3} to denote inversions

Author: Schenker, Heinrich
notes_1: *: No music notation, just plain text

Author: Jones, Robert Gomer
notes_1: pp.20: Using the single-quote notation for augmented triads; pp.30: Figured bass and Roman numerals in same row; pp.161: Very well-explained example of diatonic modulation

Author: Piston, Walter
notes_1: *: Piston uses both syntaxes (V of V) and (V/V). The slash appears later in the book, I haven't realized if there are specific indications of what it means and when the slash is used instead of "of"; Piston went as far as "degree of N" and "Ger of degree"; the syntax is pretty advanced at this stage; second edition here: https://archive.org/details/harmonypist00pist/page/n7/mode/2up

Book: A concentrated course in traditional harmony
Author: Hindemith, Paul
notes_1: *: Editions are weird for this one; it seems that the English version came out first (1943), before the German edition (1948), even tho Hindemith was German. Hindemith talks about "secondary dominants", but does not provide a syntax for them, other than figured bass

Author: Bairstow, Edward Cuthbert
notes_1: *: Got a kindle version because it was very cheap

Author: Murphy, Howard Ansley and Stringham, Edwin John
Ottman, Robert W.
notes_1: pp75: First time I see lower case Roman numerals instead of smaller-cased ones; pp.148: Using the + notation for augmented triads

Author: Tischler, Hans
notes_1: pp.163: Using + syntax for augmented triads; pp.225: Use of N6 notation for Neapolitan; pp.232: Right before the first tonicization, a D/degree notation where "D" can be replaced by any dominant chosen by the student; pp.233: Tonicization first appears; *: lower case instead of small case in Roman numerals

Author: Goldman, Richard Franko
notes_1: pp.58: V7ofV notation; pp.59: Another V7ofVI, chose this one because the previous had an error; pp.79: N6 notation for Neapolitan; pp.86: It, Fr, German notation for augsix chords; pp.89: Some examples of V7ofN

Author: Mitchell, William John
notes_1: pp.212: Applied dominants notation (V-I underneath), using the term "applied dominants" explicitly; pp.223: Alternative notation of applied dominants

Author: Schoenberg, Arnold
notes_1: *: Published after Schoenberg's death; ideas are potentially much older

Author: Schoenberg, Arnold
notes_1: *: Published after Schoenberg's death; ideas are potentially much older

Book: Tonal harmony in concept and practice
Author: Forte, Allen

Book: Tonal harmony: with an introduction to twentieth-century music
Author: Kostka, Stefan M. and Payne, Dorothy
notes_1: *: Second edition here: https://archive.org/details/tonalharmonywith00stef
